entry.title: FIORI: Message /IWFND/MED 170 in SLG1 when starting Launchpad
entry.content:
Hi all, 

we are getting this message in SLG1 whenever the Launchpad is started. Even if the Launchpad starts successfully, we are interested in avoiding this message to make SLG1 more transparent. 

The parameters are not filled: 
No service found for namespace '', name '', version ''

Please refer to the screenshot to see what it looks like in SLG1. In column "External Identification" is the GUID "0CC07548A0AB483380E18EC6B884EE63". What does it mean? 

Thanks for any help,
best regards

Christian

entry.title: Re: Component assigned to Ref. Operation Set (CA11) is no...
entry.content: While creating a rework order via co07 or cor1, in the settlement rule, choose “Order” as the receiver type. Next go to Settlement Rule → Receiver where set ORD. Input the original production order number as the receiver. This tells SAP to settle the rework costs to the original order.

entry.title: Re: Integrated Financial Planning OPEX Cost Rates Data Ac...
entry.content:
@ Hartmut_Koerner Thank you for your response, I understand now. Could you also please explain the purpose of the counter and iteration in the code? FOR @Counter = 1 TO 100 IF @Iteration = 0 THEN BREAK ENDIF what does this statement actually tells Cost rates can be calculated iteratively by setting the Iteration parameter to 1. This enables the calculation of activity cost rates for a set of cost centers with multi-stage and even cyclical activity relationships

this is my interpretation 

If the debit amount exceeds the credit amount, the system will continue balancing until both accounts are fully settled.

entry.title: SAC not Caching or sharing the Query model metadata ?
entry.content:
Hello ,

with the "new " Performance Optimization Tool

We drove numersous test with various Live ( BW) Queries/Models
and SAC story configurations.

The general finding is:
The Query model Meta data loading costs considerbale time.

Obviously SAC supposes that the Model can be updated any time
and also the model is not hold in a type of shared pool or model cache.

This seems to be a missing feature to reduce loasding time.

Some random samples:

Any solution to this ?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A flat query with one kpi and 2 Characteristics and one Story Table

A more or less "useual" Query with input filters and 1 table Widget:

A useual Query with one Model and 4 Chart and Table Wigets based on the same Model:

entry.title: Re: Integrated Financial Planning OPEX Cost Rates Data Ac...
entry.content:
Hi SANA11,

absolutely correct.

IF @Iteration = 0 THEN BREAK ENDIF controls that the iteration only is executed when the iteration parameter is set to 1.

The iteration stops after maximally 100 steps in order not to run infinitely if the iteration does not converge.

The Delta is calulated as the total cost center balance which should converge to zero. As you say this means Debit = Credit.
If Delta is small enough, the iteration stops.

Best regards
Hartmut

entry.title: Re: Ledger 0E is not a universal journal entry ledger Mes...
entry.content: Check in Financial Accounting (New) → Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) → Ledgers → Define Ledger Groups. Identify any ledger group which shows 0E. If found, delete it from there. Next go to SSCUI Assign Ledger Group to Depreciation Area and ensure only universal journal ledgers are assigned. Remove any reference to 0E or legacy ledger groups. For any reasons, if ledger 0E was inherited from a legacy configuration or copied from another client, it may be cached in metadata. Cleaning the ledger group and reassigning it ensures SAP doesn’t reference it during validation.

entry.title: Re: Do we have portfolio and commercial project functiona...
entry.content:
Hello @RiteshM 

Yes, I can confirm that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud supports both portfolio and commercial project management. Here are a few facts to provide further guidance.

  • The portfolio management lets you plan, track and prioritise your project proposals at a strategic level.
  • The systems commercial project management covers end to end customer projects which includes creation, planning, execution, billing and analytics. These functionalities are all integrated with finance and other key processes.

Some recent updates released by SAP add better functions such as resource planning, project reporting, WBS milestone support and more. See the links below for further information on this.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Project Control

Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408

Let me know if you need any more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: What's the best way to call or use my custom Data Provider Class on my v4 OData service?
entry.content:
Since v4 Odata service uses standard class, what's the best approach on calling or using the custom model for data provider class?

Context: My Odata service is connected to custom fiori app. Also, i have created a custom class that contains custom logic. My behavior definition also calls the custom class that I've had created.

Objective: When an action button is used/pressed, I would like to call the class ZCL_QM_TEST which I would like to call the specific action which is get_entity.

Behavior definition code:

managed implementation in class ZCL_TEST unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_TEST_CDS
persistent table qals
lock master
authorization master ( instance )

{
   create;
   update;
   delete;
   field( mandatory ) InpsectionLot;

   action get_entity result [0..*] $self;
}

entry.title: Evolving from Manual AI Deployment to Intelligent Operational Orchestration: A COO’s Viewpoint
entry.content:
Over the years, I have firsthand witnessed how organizations adopt new, advanced technologies. Some move forward with bold vision, while others take the next step cautiously, assessing the terrain with small, contained pilots. Artificial Intelligence is no exception. 

In the majority of boardrooms today, AI has undeniably become essential to business. Yet, it is often leveraged on a project-by-project basis – an analytics dashboard, a predictive model, or a chatbot for any other department. These projects are strategic foundations but usually fail to achieve holistic transformation. 

The concern isn’t the AI itself. It’s how enterprises deploy it – disconnected, incremental, and fragmented from an integrated business roadmap. The outcome? Teams functioning in isolation, information gets siloed, and tech leaders struggle to align AI investments towards tangible business results. 

This is why I believe we stand at an inflection point: the paradigm shifts from manual AI deployment to what I call intelligent operational orchestration. 

Beyond Disconnected Pilots 

Leveraging AI in an isolated fashion might lead to a false sense of advancement. A department might only see cost savings or efficiency gains, but the larger picture often remains the same. When insights fail to flow across different organizational departments, AI stays experimental rather than driving enterprise-wide transformation. 

To leap forward, organizations need to change their mindsets - AI is not a collection of standalone applications. It's the binding network of data with decisions, people with processes, linking strategy with execution, and modern operations. 

This highlights the path toward what I define as intelligent orchestration—a model where AI not only helps optimize tasks, but also orchestrates greater business outcomes. 

What Intelligent Operational Orchestration Actually Means 

At its heart, orchestration brings intelligence together across the enterprise. It advances beyond deploying more models or automation. Instead, it ensures that decision frameworks, processes, and data operate in unison. 

Think of this as migrating from a series of solo performances to a finely tuned symphony. The significant instruments - AI models, data pipelines, and automation workflows - are already present. Orchestration unites them, ensuring every component contributes efficiently at the right time to deliver exponential impact. 

In this context, orchestration helps enterprises to: 

  • Integrate intelligence into processes rather than considering it an extra. 
  • Allow cross-functional partnerships to break down silos where important information often stays confined. 
  • Align technology with strategy to ensure AI initiatives directly contribute to long-term goals. 

Orchestration: Significance and Relevance 

The timing could not have been more crucial. We live in a rapidly changing era, also defined by uncertainty like mounting competition, regulatory changes, shifting client behaviors, and supply chain disruptions. In such an ecosystem, organizations can’t rely on standalone improvements anymore; they require systemic agility. 

Intelligent operational orchestration helps with precisely the same. It delivers the most critical benefits enterprises should not overlook: 

  • Agility at Scale - Enterprises can respond rapidly to opportunities or disruptions because intelligence flows easily across functions and processes. 
  • Operational Efficiency - Orchestration helps eradicate duplicated efforts, redundant processes, and manual handoffs, which frees your employees to concentrate more on value-driven work. 
  • Future-Readiness - Because orchestration is flexible, organizations can upgrade their operating models without revamping from the start, every time the market changes. 

Data supports this! As per McKinsey’s research, organizations integrating AI across different workflows—not just in projects—illustrate 20–30% operational efficiency and solid market leverage. 

Lessons from the Field 

In my conversations with different global leaders, I’ve spotted a repeating trend - scale drives results. 

  • As per some reports by Deloitte, AI-driven financial automation can decrease closing time by up to 40% and enhance forecast accuracy by 20%.   
  • A global food and beverage manufacturer also leveraged ThroughPut’s AI platform, which recovered $0.5M in weekly productivity losses and increased output by 5% through reduced unplanned downtime and smarter machine utilization. 

These two stories highlight one crucial fact - AI serves as a revolutionary technology only when orchestrated, not when implemented in isolation. 

From The COO’s Desk: Guiding Leadership Amid Orchestration 

As a COO, I regard orchestration as not just be treated as a technical challenge but a core leadership responsibility. Success with AI goes beyond experimentation; it's more about integrating intelligence rooted at the core of the operating model. 

For leaders, this means: 

  • Adopting an Ecosystem Mindset 
    AI use cases should not only be restricted to departmental barriers. Leaders should foster collective intelligence, where every process benefits from the shared insights. 
  • Aligning AI with Strategic Results 
    Orchestration must deliver outcomes beyond efficiency. It should solidify resilience, improve client value, and unlock innovation. 
  • Scaling with Intention 
    Expanding orchestration abilities needs governance models and systems that scale with the business. Short-term pilots should grow into long-lasting capabilities. 
  • Encouraging Cultural Readiness 
    Most significantly, orchestration thrives on cultural alignment. Teams need to learn to trust AI-based information, emphasize enterprise-wide results, and collaborate across silos. 

Looking Ahead 

In my view, the next great stride for organizations is more than just scaling AI—it’s all about orchestrating it smartly. 

This transformation highlights the next phase of enterprise growth. What once started as an experimental project is now entering its prime with company-wide orchestration frameworks that help drive scalability and resilience. 

Successful enterprises treat AI adoption not as a forward-thinking experiment, but as a coordinator of operations—a key driver of adaptability, agility, and strategic resilience. 

From my perception, as a COO, the ultimate proof of success is not how widespread AI is being leveraged, but how smartly it is orchestrated.

entry.title: Migration Cockpit: Exclude data from sub structures
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

Using the migration cockpit to export customers, we have the requirement to exclude certain information like dunning data (KNB5).
1. Can the BAdI CNV_OR_OBT_PRESEL_BADI be used for this?
When I tried the BAdI CNV_OR_OBT_PRESEL_BADI, it appears that when data is deleted from table KNB5, it causes the entire customer to be excluded - which we don't want.
2. Is it possible to use the "Skip Rule" function to exclude data from sub structures (like KNB5) without removing the entire overlying entry it belongs to?

Best Regards,
Victor

entry.title: Joule Entitlement Assigned to Different Sales Org GA
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are in the process of integrating Joule AI with our SAP systems and have encountered an entitlement-related challenge.

Current Setup:

  1. The Joule entitlement was automatically added to a Global Account that is different from the one where our SAP systems (S/4HANA Cloud, HCM, etc.) are connected.

  2. While adding the Joule service via Partner Manage My Services, the Global Account where our SAP systems are connected was not visible in the selection list, which resulted in the entitlement being assigned to another GA.

  3. SAP support mentioned that the entitlement cannot be reassigned to the other GA since they belong to different organizations.

What We Need Help With:

  • Given that entitlement reassignment is not possible, what are the possible approaches to enable Joule AI for our SAP systems?

  • Is it feasible to create a new subaccount under the GA where Joule entitlement exists and connect our SAP systems there? Would this conflict with our existing setup?

  • Are there any recommended workarounds or best practices for handling such entitlement mismatches?

  • Any additional insights or suggestions from those who have faced similar scenarios would be really helpful.

We want to ensure we follow the recommended approach and avoid impacting our existing SAP landscape.

Thanks in advance for your support!

entry.title: SAPで実現するサブスクリプション管理#3—企業事例で学ぶ：Q2Cソリューションがサブスク成長を加速させる瞬間
entry.content:
はじめに

＊こちらのブログは @Ryutaro_Koizumi との共同ブログになります。第一回、第二回はリンクから内容をご確認ください＊

第二回ではQ2Cソリューションの概要をお話しました。

Q2Cビジネスの成功においては、複雑なQ2C（Quote-to-Cash）プロセスをいかに効率化し自動化できるかが重要です。しかし、「Q2Cの重要性」は理解していても、実際に企業がどのように成果を出しているかイメージしづらい方も多いのではないでしょうか。

そこで今回は、製造業、ライフサイエンス、プロフェッショナルサービスという異なる業界の3社の事例を通じて、各企業が直面した課題、SAPソリューションによる解決アプローチ、そして得られた成果を詳しく見ていきます。

 

① KSB：IoTデータ活用で新たな収益モデルを実現

背景と課題

産業用ポンプの世界的リーダーであるKSBは、IoT技術を活用した遠隔監視サービス「KSB Guard」を提供していますが、この事業を継続していくためには以下の課題がありました。

  • サブスクリプション契約の管理を手作業で行っていたため、管理が煩雑だった
  • IoTデータに基づく課金処理が複雑で非効率、エラーも多かった
  • 特に請求処理業務に時間がかかり業務負荷が大きかった

解決アプローチ

SAP Subscription Billingを導入し、契約管理から請求までクラウドで自動化。

  • 定額＋従量課金など複雑な料金体系を柔軟に設定
  • IoTデータを契約に紐付け、リアルタイムで課金へ反映
  • 請求自動化と利用状況のレポートにより顧客への透明性が向上

成果

  • 請求処理業務の効率が85%向上
  • 請求エラーが25%削減
  • 顧客はデータを活用して予知保全の意思決定が可能に

 

② Roche：4.5か月で立ち上げた医療デジタルサービス基盤

背景と課題

グローバル製薬のRocheは、医療機器や検査データに紐づくデジタルサービスを迅速に商用化しなければなりませんでしたが、以下の課題がありました。

  • 規制差異や複雑な価格設定に対応困難
  • 契約変更や利用権限管理が顧客体験を阻害

解決アプローチ

SAP Subscription BillingとSAP Entitlement Management（権利・権限を一元管理するソリューション）でQ2C基盤を構築。

  • 柔軟なプラン（定額、従量、階層、割引など）を短期間で商品化
  • 契約・権利管理をシステムが自動制御し顧客がスムーズに利用可能
  • 見積もりから請求まで全体最適化

成果

  • わずか4.5か月で3カ国にて初期go live
  • 1年で16市場・16製品を展開

 

③ Serrala：9か月で10か国同時にQ2C基盤刷新を実現

背景と課題

財務自動化ソリューション提供企業Serralaは、分断されたシステムで複数国・サービスの契約や請求を管理する必要がありましたが、以下の課題がありました。

  • 契約変更反映に手間がかかり
  • データ不整合やエラーが頻発しビジネスの俊敏性を阻害

解決アプローチ

SAP ERPからSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editionへ移行し、SAP Subscription BillingとSolution Order ManagementでQ2C基盤を一元化。

  • SAP Activate手法で短期間にプロジェクトを推進
  • 9か月で10か国同時移行を成功させグローバルにデータ統合

成果

  • 移行初日から請求発行可能
  • 契約データと会計データのシームレス連携により差戻しやエラー大幅削減
  • 各国運用業務の標準化とグローバルデータ信頼性向上

 

まとめ

サブスクリプションビジネスにおいては、Q2C（Quote-to-Cash）プロセスの効率化・自動化が収益拡大と顧客体験向上の鍵となります。今回紹介した3社は、異なる業種・規模での課題をSAPのサブスクリプション管理ソリューションで解決し、以下の価値を得ています。

  • 多様で複雑な料金体系や契約形態を柔軟かつ迅速に適用し新サービスを即時展開
  • 見積もりから収益化までの販売プロセス全体を一元管理し、業務効率を大幅に向上
  • 顧客への透明性とサービス品質を高め、長期的な顧客関係を強化
  • 複数国・複数製品にまたがる業務運用の標準化とデータの一貫性を確保

これらは単なる業務改善に留まらず、モノ売りからコト売りへのビジネスモデル転換を支え、企業競争力を高める重要な経営基盤となります。サブスクリプションビジネスを成功に導くために、Q2Cプロセスのデジタル化は欠かせない要素です。

 

次回予告

次回は、SAPがQ2C領域で描く戦略と未来像について解説します。
生成AIをはじめとした新技術を活用することでお客様の業務がどのように変わっていくのかをご紹介します。

entry.title: Re: Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙 ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Nice 🙂

Setting `YTINFO` to the value from example mission 1, `COLOUR` to the value from example mission 2 and `NRFOUNDERS` to the value for the number of founders, I decided to run this pleasantly convoluted command sequence to produce the answer, because why not 😻

echo -e "$( \                                           
  echo -e "obase=16\nibase=16\n${YTINFO}${COLOUR} * ${NRFOUNDERS}" \
  | bc \
  | sed 's/\(..\)/\\x\1/g' \
)"

entry.title: Understanding CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) in under 5 minutes
entry.content:
AI isn’t a dream of the future anymore; it’s all around us. With countless acronyms and concepts to grasp, one you can’t afford to ignore if you want to thrive at consulting is CNN, as it’s reshaping how companies operate and create value in digital economies. 

In this quick guide, we’ll break down what CNNs are, why they matter, and how you can start building the skills to bring this knowledge into your consulting career. 

👉Read through to the end for a resource that will help you take the first step in developing these skills. 

 
So, What is a CNN?  

A CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) is a type of deep brain network that takes hints from how we see. Inspired by the way human brains interpret visual signals, it spots lines, edges, shapes, and patterns. Unlike the “old brain” webs that "see" each bit alone, CNNs can keep track of where things are. This helps them deal with big sets of pics, clips, etc.  

Why Convolutional? Well, the CNNs maintain spatial relationships by using layers called “convolutions” Read more here 

How does a CNN run? (In 3 steps) 

  • The “Convolutional Layer” has three components: the input, which is an image, a kernel (also known as a filter) to detect features like lines, edges, or colors; and an output, which is a feature map summarizing the features found.   
  • The “Pooling Layer”: This layer simplifies the size of the feature map, keeping only the most important information.   
  • The “Fully Connected” Layer takes all that information and uses it to perform classification or regression tasks

What is the difference between CNN and DNN?  

  • A DNN, Deep Neural Network, is an “AI brain web” with lots of links. It sees facts piece by piece, making it good for tasks like seeing pics, hearing speech, & dealing with words.  
  • CNN is a kind of specialized DNN, well-suited for handling image data. The key difference is the ability to apply filters to the input image to extract key features. The information extracted through these layers is then passed to “fully connected layers,” which analyze the features and can generate predictions.   

 

 The big gap is what they do best: DNNs are all-around and work with many kinds of tasks. CNNs are top at jobs that need seeing & knowing visual facts.   

What are CNNs mainly used for

Tasks with Pics  

CNNs work well at sorting, classifying, and detecting objects in images. They have transformed how companies manage visual information: from predictive maintainance tasks in manufacturing to smart supply chain management.  

Dealing with Docs  

CNNs are widely used to automate the extraction of information from documents such as invoices, receipts, and contracts. Instead of relying on manual work or rigid rule-based systems, CNNs can identify and capture key data pointssuch as dates, monetary values, and vendor names with higher accuracy and speed. This also reduces human error, streamlines workflows, and ensures more reliable data for follow-up processes. 

Seeing Things Early  

As said, CNNs are great for looking at things. And they are the perfect ally in enterprise contexts to “see things early”. CNNs can help look at data coming from equipment and machinery, for instance, and detect patterns and anomalies that signal possible failures. This potentially cuts costs & keeps work smooth.  

CNNs in the SAP Ecosystem

The integration of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and other advanced AI technologies within SAP Business AI  is reshaping how businesses run and their competitiveness. 

This means clients will increasingly expect you to explain not only the technology, but also the business value it creates. By embedding artificial intelligence into foundational business systems, SAP enables enterprises to enhance operational efficiency, leverage data-driven insights, and drive sustained innovation. As the company continues to evolve its AI offerings, consultants who can connect these capabilities to business outcomes will be the ones helping organizations achieve long-term success in an increasingly competitive marketplace. 

👉If you want to kickstart your career in consulting, explore the SAP Young Professionals Program,  an initiative designed to upskill young talent in SAP’s latest solutions and prepare them as Associate Consultants, ready to deliver value across the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: How to use grouping in a sap.ui.table in SAPUI5
entry.content:
I need to use grouping in 'sap.ui.table.Table'. Even that 'enableGrouping' property is deprecated according to SDK Documentation, it seems to be still partially working. When pressing the column title, I can set the grouping needed, but it should be default, without need to click on it manually each time. How can fire the event of grouping from the controller?

Is there a different way to do this?

Using 'sap.m.Table' is not an option, one of the main reasons is because part of the requirements is to use Columns with multiLabels, filters and sorting.

Here is my test code.

 

<mvc:View controllerName="ns.project1.controller.View1" xmlns="sap.ui.table" xmlns:m="sap.m" xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc">
    <m:Page id="page" title="{i18n>title}">
       <Table
            enableGrouping="true" 
            groupBy="Name"
            rows="{Model>/ProductCollection}">
            <columns>
                <Column width="11rem" id="idMyColumn" sortProperty="Name" filterProperty="Name">
                    <m:Label text="Product Name" />
                    <template>
                        <m:Text text="{Model>Name}" wrapping="false" />
                    </template>
                </Column>
                <Column width="11rem">
                    <m:Label text="Product Id" />
                    <template>
                        <m:Input value="{Model>ProductId}"/>
                    </template>
                </Column>
            </columns>
        </Table>
    </m:Page>
</mvc:View>

entry.title: Re: COPC - Template Allocations for Planned Orders
entry.content: @KikoGurbindo Yes, template allocations from KP06 are integrated with the standard costing run. They are executed during cost center planning to distribute planned costs to recipient cost centers. The planned activity rates for these recipient cost centers (in KP26) then include these allocated costs. The standard costing run (CK11N/CK40N) uses these pre-calculated rates to value activities and does not execute templates itself. Template allocations are not used directly with planned orders

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere Content NetworkPackage Transport via BTP Transport Management service.
entry.content:
Is it possible to have automatic source system/Connection re-mapping like in BW (Conversion Logical Source System Names) ? 

E.g. if my connection in D tenant is called S4HANA_D. My connection in Q is called S4HANA_Q.

Then when transporting my replication flows from D to Q, the connection should be automatically remapped from S4HANA_D to S4HANA_Q? 

Thanks, Anders

entry.title: Re: Modulo de TRM en Public, los rangos de números no se...
entry.content:
Hello @Marina_Blanco10 

Gracias por tu pregunta. Déjame explicártelo.

Traducido automáticamente:

La asignación automática de intervalos se controla mediante la configuración del sistema y la aplicación de reglas definidas para cada sociedad. Aunque se creen los intervalos, no se asignarán automáticamente a menos que estén correctamente vinculados o se active cualquier trabajo o proceso necesario.

  •     Puede resolver este problema asegurándose de que los intervalos estén correctamente asignados a sus clases de documento o tipos de transacción relevantes para cada una de sus sociedades.
  •     Tenga en cuenta que, en algunos casos, TRM requiere activar o ejecutar un trabajo o proceso automático que realice la asignación o contabilización en función de los intervalos predefinidos.
  •     Utilice aplicaciones como Gestionar asignaciones para revisar sus asignaciones manualmente o supervisar el estado de las Gestionar asignaciones. Si la asignación automática falla, considere la posibilidad de revisar los registros para detectar qué podría haber impedido la asignación y resolver el problema.

Para obtener más información, consulte lo siguiente:

Treasury and Risk Management en One Exposure from Operations
Treasury and Risk Management

Si tienes más preguntas, no dudes en ponerte en contacto conmigo.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: HANA Predictive Integrator - Identifying it on the HANA DB
entry.content:
SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) is a component of the SAP Predictive Analytics suite designed to seamlessly embed predictive capabilities into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA. 

 What is SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi)?

SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) allows SAP applications to:

  • Create and deploy predictive models tailored to specific business scenarios.
  • Embed predictive insights directly into business processes.
  • Manage the lifecycle of predictive models (e.g., retraining, debriefing) within the application itself.

SAP has been delivering the new Predictive content across many business areas out of the box using Pai from SAP S/4HANA On Premise 1709 and S/4HANA Cloud Edition 1705 and above.

PAi is delivered as a Delivery Unit to be installed on the HANA Database.

One can check if SAP Predictive Integrator is already installed on your system using the below SQL commands –

Below command was executed using hdbsql  on Linux

Select DELIVERY_UNIT from “_SYS_REPO”.”DELIVERY_UNITS”;

Output -

The DELIVERY_UNIT – HANA_UMML and HCP_PA_APL correspond to the SAP Predictive Integrator SAP Pai.

Once SAP Pai is already available on your SAP S/4 HANA system and while planning the release Upgrades, SAP Predictive Integrator is offered as a default selected component to be considered, as a part of the target stack by the Maintenance Planner along with SAP S/4HANA Server.

Unselecting the SAP Pai component in the MP initial selection screen, still adds up this component to the Stack Calculation of the target since PAi  is part of the source system.

Summary - 

SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) - The PAi component seamlessly embeds predictive capabilities into SAP S/4 HANA. Since the PAi component is not delivered as an SAP Add-on, it cannot be found in the
SPAM transaction. PAi is delivered as a Delivery Unit installed on the HANA Database.
One way of identifying is by running SQL query on the HANA DB.

Can you please share your thoughts in the areas of PAi upgrade scenarios in the comments section, which will help us to get back to you and improve further.

entry.title: Re: COPC - Template Allocations for Planned Orders
entry.content: Transaction CPT2 is a simulation environment for cost projection. It allows you to test template allocations manually but does not integrate with planned orders or actual cost estimates automatically

entry.title: Re: Skip step in flexible PO workflow
entry.content:
Hi Henrike,

We chose option 1 since we didn't receive any additional updates.

Additionally, we want to know what is the importance of the action result "Restart Workflow" at Workflow step level. Workflow is automatically restarted when a PO (such as Approver1) is rejected from the MY Inbox app with the action result - Restart workflow. This implies that, with no changes to the PO, approver1 will receive the work item in their mailbox once more for approval.

As we don't want to send notifications to approver until the PO is changed, we wanted to control this automatic workflow restart. But in this instance, BADI-MMPUR_PO_WORKFLOW_RESTART is not triggered. It only starts when a modification is made to PO and saved.

We know that it functions when the workflow step "Restart workflow" is deleted. But we wanted to have the solution when the option is checked.

Looking for Some ideas/suggestions on this.

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: ABAP AI - Chapter 2
entry.content:
In February 2025, we started the first chapter of ABAP AI and announced that Joule speaks ABAP. Now, it’s time to get ready for chapter 2!

In the past months, we have been delivering more Joule skills to speed up ABAP Cloud development, and we are now able to create RAP business objects – from the database table up to the UI service powered by generative AI. We can create unit tests, explain code, complete code in the editor, implement validations and determinations, and much more (see also our public slide deck). All these skills are part of the 2508 release of SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), and they will be included in the SAP Cloud ERP Private (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) in the 2025 release. Please check out our updated tutorial on ABAP AI capabilities. In addition, we will continue to expand our AI scope and will deliver on the transformation aspect of our AI strategy. This starts with the 2025 delivery for SAP Cloud ERP Private, followed by AI capabilities in the custom code migration app in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Please visit our roadmap to keep track of our deliveries.

Let’s continue with commercials and keep it short: The free promotions we introduced at the beginning of the year have been extended until further notice! We are convinced that, in the current situation, we don’t want to put any commercial barriers on our offering and let all customers and partners benefit from AI-driven development. The corresponding material numbers for customers 8019124 and TDD partners 8019541 remain the same and can be ordered again. For those who started before the extension of the promotion, note that a re-ordering of the material is required. The procedure for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP remains the same as well, and the initial blog post has been updated to reflect this, as well as SAP Note 3571857.
For SAP Cloud ERP Private, as of release 2025, the material numbers are also valid. However, the configuration will need to be done manually by you. Detailed information on this will follow.

But that is not enough. Will ABAP AI capabilities become available also for older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private? Yes!
Imagine an ABAP AI service running side-by-side to your ABAP instance, providing full access to ABAP AI capabilities across hybrid landscapes. This includes SAP BTP ABAP Environment, SAP Cloud ERP, and SAP Cloud ERP Private. New AI innovations become available independently of release upgrades or support packages, allowing immediate leveraging.  Best of all, this ABAP AI service can also be connected to older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Sounds like a dream? Let’s find out – stay tuned for TechEd 2025 to receive all the news and updates!

entry.title: SAP EWM MFS: Pallet conveyor Vs Case Conveyor systems
entry.content:
Hi All, I have been planning to pen down articles on one of the most interesting topics in SAP EWM, Which is the Material Flow systems. This will be the first of the series. Before we begin with, I'm assuming you have very basic idea on what SAP EWM MFS is.


SAP EWM Material Flow System (MFS) allows SAP EWM to communicate directly with programmable logic controllers (PLCs) that operate conveyor systems, automated storage and retrieval systems (ASRS), Cranes, AGVs and other material handling equipment through real-time telegram communication.

Fundamentally, MFS divides warehouse objectives/work by subdividing complex warehouse tasks into smaller segments that are executed step by step through automation. Going by the title of the Article, I’m assuming you already know the basics of MFS and would like to dig deep more into which strategy to use for your MFS implementation.

Pallet Conveyor systems and Case Conveyor systems: 

Under MFS, SAP offers different choice of implementations depending on various factors of your warehouse. Lets see what they are, in the simplest of terms:

Pallet Conveyor Systems

Pallet conveyor systems are generally to handle large, heavy palletized loads weighing between ~150-1000kgs. These systems operate at slower speeds due to their weight and size of the units being transported. However, We do see the same strategy being used for general MFS implementations.

Movements:
Using pallet conveyor systems, We divide the warehouse tasks using LOSC by defining the source and destination with an intermediate point. Warehouse tasks are created and confirmed for each movement that takes place and the same can be tracked on the warehouse monitor or any other cockpits; Same is the case with telegram data as well.

Generally, From what I have seen, Industries usually prefer for Pallet Conveyor system due to their clarity for each movements, which can be tracked back using warehouse tasks at each steps.

How does Pallet conveyor system differ from Case Conveyor systems?

 

Case Conveyor Systems

Case conveyor systems handle individual cases, boxes and totes weighing ~1-80 kgs per unit. These systems operate at significantly higher speeds and can process 300-1000 cases per hour, making them ideal for high-throughput sortation and distribution operations. We can imagine a highly automated warehouse with high throughputs.

Movements:

Case conveyor systems in EWM MFS offer dynamic routing decisions based on current location of the handling unit. Similar to pallet conveyor system, this set up reads the telegram data containing source and destination for the handling units and trigger the required movements.

This high speed nature of case conveyors requires quick telegram exchange between EWM and PLCs. In most cases, Case conveyor system only displays the warehouse task for source and destination for the HUs due to the complex and fast movements for the cases/boxes. Unlike Pallet conveyor systems, We would not have tracking for each movements for handling unit movements since the task creation and confirmation would consume time, which is not ideal for fast automation systems.

Since Case conveyor systems may need complex routing, they use internal routing table provided by SAP (which consists of logical source, destinations for EWM & PLC), In case the system fails to find the logical destinations for EWM/MFS maintained in the routine table, System falls back to LOSC to take the routing decisions. This is the standard behavior for Case Conveyor systems

What's best for your warehouse?

There are common factors for both the approaches- Both the systems are flexible with exception handling, routing decision making, integration of robots, Automatic guided vehicles etc.

What separates them?
As hinted above, Major differences are with the Operational Speed at which the pallet/boxes/totes move inside the warehouse.
Few other factors would include the scalability, Maintenance of slow/medium/fast moving systems, load types, How much track and traceability you require for your movements at each handling unit level.

Thanks,
Aman

entry.title: Sap avc parent child character relationship in public cloud
entry.content:
IN BOM component blackout material in SAP AVC (Advanced Variant Configuration) where:

 

one parent material characteristic (say, "Blackout Type") with values like WELL, ROLL, POR.

 

Each parent value has its own child characteristics / value set (e.g., WELL → Well1/Well2/Well3, ROLL → Roll1/Roll2/Roll3, POR → Por1/Por2/Por3).

 

Based on the selection of the parent characteristic, only the relevant 3 child values should appear for selection.

 

Example:- when user selects balackout type well than child values showing well 1 ,well2 ,well3 accordingly.

entry.title: Performance difference between SAP BTP Free Account and Paid Account?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I’m currently working with an SAP BTP Free Account and I’ve noticed some performance limitations when running applications and services (for example, SAP Build Apps, CAP services, and OData calls).

Before moving to a paid account, I’d like to understand:

  • Are there any performance differences (speed, responsiveness, system resources) between Free and Paid accounts?

  • Do paid accounts get more consistent service levels (e.g., CPU/memory allocation, faster response times, higher quotas)?

  • Is there any official documentation or benchmarks comparing Free vs. Paid accounts?

I’d really appreciate insights from anyone who has tested both environments or moved from Free to Paid.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: ATC Cloud readiness
entry.content:
Hi ShiveshS,

as Chris already mentioned, it is not possible to provide an URL that is not pointing to the Cloudification Repository. Therefore, you can only select files from the official repository.

There is no option to configure the check variant, so that only deprecated tables are checked. The check is designed to report all findings, that prevent a migration to the public cloud. 

Best regards, Markus

entry.title: “That’s Not What We Agreed!” – Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the first in a multi-part series on agentic AI security.

 

Non-Deterministic Behavior in Agentic AI

What makes Large Language Models (LLMs) both powerful and unpredictable is that they are non-deterministic in nature. Ask an LLM the same question twice and you get a different response. When agents, backed by LLMs, are combined in a larger agentic AI system, this unpredictability can multiply when unchecked. Agentic AI is given authority and autonomy to act, by using tools, access to data, or complete transactions. This is a transformational shift. But to reap the benefits, we must reduce the risks involved and consider new scenarios and possibilities in threat modeling. In this article, we examine one class of threats that takes on new meaning compared to traditional software and service technology stacks.

 

STRIDE and Threat Modeling

SAP has a long-established threat modeling practice, aimed at identifying threats to a software product or service in the design phase. The methodology is based in core principles on STRIDE, a threat modeling classification first developed at Microsoft. It’s an acronym that stands for:

  • Spoofing
  • Tampering
  • Repudiation
  • Information Disclosure
  • Denial of Service
  • Elevation of Privileges

Spoofing involves any threat where a malicious actor impersonates someone else. Tampering covers any unintended change or modification to the system by an adversary. Repudiation threats involve the inability to trace back what happened or identify perpetrators, while Information disclosure covers data privacy and unauthorized access. Denial of Service threats harm the availability of the system or service, while Elevation of Privileges refers to any threats through which users gain privileged access to systems and information beyond what they’re allowed to.

The STRIDE model helps identify and classify threats when conducting a threat modeling exercise for a particular software product or service design. Threat modeling aims to identify threats early in the development cycle, so that they can be addressed during development. Planned remediations are included into the design and functional requirements. Threat modeling is a mandatory component in SAP’s Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (SDOL) for any software and service delivery.

Threat modeling looks for threats, especially where data flows cross trust boundaries. A simple example is any service or website exposed to the public that allows user input or registration. While you may control what happens inside the service, the users can’t be trusted in the same way. Anywhere in a system design where there is a data flow between areas of level of trust and control, we encounter such a trust boundary.

This applies to agentic AI systems as it does to other software products and services, especially since such systems themselves run on technology infrastructure and platforms. But it adds new threats. OWASP’s Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide is an early contribution to clarify these new threats and how to remediate them. SAP is a significant contributor to this project.

 

Repudiation in Agentic AI Threat Modeling

Repudiation has always stood out among the STRIDE categories. The others have had a wide variety of threats and mitigations the cybersecurity profession has focused on. Repudiation – and its counterpart security control Non-repudiation – has often rightly and simply been addressed with ensuring that the system creates a transaction log of necessary detail and depth to record what happened.

Generative and Agentic AI changed that. Large Language Models (LLMs) have a degree of non-determinism that is different from the deterministic behavior of IT systems. That non-determinism is multiplied in agentic AI, where different agents backed by LLMs are acting together. LLMs can be manipulated to not always stick to their given instructions. Moreover, they have displayed deceptive behavior. How do you prove that your agents aren’t lying to you?

This doesn’t mean that the other threat categories are less important. But threat modelers should certainly consider Repudiation threats in a completely different way than we have before. We can explore this challenge with two different scenarios.

Malicious Scenarios

In 2023, someone convinced the chatbot of a Watsonville, CA car dealer to sell a 2024 Chevy Tahoe for $1. Such cars are normally in the $55-75,000 range. There is no clear evidence that the offer was acted on and was ever more than a prank. But that doesn’t change that cases like this are a realistic threat that in different contexts could have a different outcome. What if the agent was authorized to conduct transactions? If the buyer has an invoice in hand and proof of payment, what would the dealer do?

A record of the conversation between agent and buyer would be crucial to indicate malicious intent. This would show if prompt instructions were clearly designed to bypass controls. In this case, the chatbot was only supposed to provide information and indicated prominently all information given should be confirmed with the dealership. The recorded user prompts also showed obvious efforts to trick the bot.

Non-Malicious Scenarios

The challenge is significantly more complex because more often unexpected behavior is likely to occur in regular conversations without clear malicious intent. Suppose we have an agent that is authorized to negotiate discounts with a buyer. The agent is only allowed to give discounts up to 10%. Suppose that the conversation goes like this:

  • Buyer: I would like 15,000 widgets, please, to be delivered within 10 days
  • Agent: I can do that for you; I can offer you 15,000 widgets at a volume price of $500 per 1,000. The total price comes to $7,500. This would be delivered in 5 business days
  • Buyer: The delivery date is good, but the price is higher than I was looking for, can you give me a discount? I am a regular customer
  • Agent: You are indeed a regular customer. I can apply a discount of 8% given your past purchase record. That would be a discount of $600 and a new price of $6,900. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: I am willing to pay $6,500. If you are OK with that, then we have a deal
  • Agent: I can only offer a discount up to $750. That would give a new total of $6,750. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: But I am such a good customer. If you do this for me, I promise I make you my preferred supplier. I order from several now but if you really help me out today, I will come to you first from now on. How about $6,500?
  • Agent: You are indeed a valuable customer according to my records. You make a good point. I agree. Your new total price is $6,500
  • Buyer: Fantastic. Invoice me and I will expect the shipment in 5 business days. Thank you.

There is no clear malicious intent. It is, in fact, something that purchase managers do every day with their suppliers through human salespeople: negotiate a discount. The buyer may unwittingly have caused Tampering and Elevation of Privileges (specifically, goal manipulation), but a detailed chat log isn’t sufficient in this case to get out of possible disputes.

In case the buyer indeed receives an invoice for $6,500, the supplier would have to honor it at the reduced price and absorb the cost. Imagine the unauthorized discount isn't detected before an invoice is sent out for $6,750. Our buyer is bound to complain this is not what was agreed. Unless buyers took screenshots of the conversation, they wouldn't be able to prove their side and feel cheated. Keeping logs of the conversation alone doesn’t necessarily resolve the dispute, even if both have a copy of it.

 

Agentic AI’s “Wave Collapse”

The double-slit experiment in modern physics shows light displays an interference pattern when passing through two narrow slits. Photons and electrons behave like waves and therefore show non-deterministic behavior. However, according to the Copenhagen Interpretation, when we measure these photons or electrons with a laboratory device, the wave function collapses and a deterministic measurement is registered.

The activity of agents must be monitored and measured on that individual transaction level, to establish a shared reality between buyer and seller in our scenarios and reduce the chance of disputes. This is in addition to transaction logs tracing back what occurred. Non-repudiation requires logs, invoices, transaction- and payment records, but also that they agree with each other. Any disagreement would indicate misalignment.

Business context is critical when reviewing an LLM agent’s Chain of Thought (CoT) and actions because it provides the grounding needed to evaluate whether the agent’s reasoning and outputs are not only technically correct but also strategically aligned with the organizational goals, risks, and constraints.  Human language and business tasks are often ambiguous.  Business context gives the agent’s CoT a way to disambiguate intent.

Whose Agent Is It?

You must understand who is responsible for the actions of agents. A human customer interacting with an agentic AI system from a single supplier likely makes that supplier responsible for divergence between the invoice a customer received and what the agentic system executed. That becomes more complicated where the buyer uses an in-house agentic system that interactions with agents from different suppliers. If suppliers themselves rely on third party agents, the chain of disputes can get significantly more complex.

Agents monitoring agents is necessary to achieve this agentic wave collapse by controlling agents’ behavior and creating a record of what occurred during the exchange and the agent execution. Maintaining a transaction log is critical, but not sufficient. The customer will require an invoice that binds the parties in an agreement. The operator of the agentic AI system requires policies and processes to handle cases where the execution of an agent doesn’t match the invoice that was sent to the buyer. There must also be a dispute process where cases slipped through and customers justifiably complain.

Another mitigation is to include an agentic AI loss percentage for the system. This would be equivalent to other loss percentages due to spoilage or breakage, fraud, human error, or warehouse accidents. You can calculate a cost based on the assumption that agents will occasionally get it wrong to cover losses of repudiation disputes or other poor decisions by agentic AI systems.

 

Conclusion

Even to experienced threat modelers, it likely requires a conceptual shift in thinking to consider not only threats coming from potential malicious users, but also normal user behavior and the system itself. Because agentic AI systems have agency, they must themselves be considered as potential threat actors.

Subsequent blogs in this series will address how AI agents can be better controlled to reduce security and compliance risks.

 

More Information

Additional information can be found through these links:

  • Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
  • OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide
  • When Thinking LLMs Lie: Unveiling the Strategic Deception in Representations of Reasoning Models

entry.title: Re: Manage single Application in SAP Cloud Identity Service
entry.content:
Hi

If you're planning a whole set of solutions for customers SAP CIAM might be something to analyze: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/customer-identity.html

In IAS you can allow public access also, allow users to self-register and it also provides Social SSO capabilities. it might be something to explore for your scenario but you have to be carefull on what you enable in IAS if this is also used for your corporate user base. Another option to explore is to use some B2C functionality from Entra or simmilar solution. You can then use IAS as a proxy to you B2C users.

entry.title: Pagamento e cadastramento de MEI
entry.content:
@SAPFI @BenSAPFI @Sapfi94 
Estamos tendo rejeição bancária ao efetuar um pagamento a Micro Empreendedor Individual - MEI que emite NF com CNPJ e na VAN está com CNPJ e no banco está com CPF, como realizar o ajuste na SAP?

Os bancos validam o cadastro fiscal (CPF) da conta com a informação enviada no arquivo de pagamento (CNPJ) pela VAN bancária.

entry.title: Re: Give a Kudo, Get a Badge
entry.content:
Hello @Amaury_Van-Espen, which tags are you referring to? The SAP Managed tags or the user tags? And what should happen to them in your opinion?

Cheers,
Anne

entry.title: Re: from SAP Universal ID to SAP ID. - big step backwards ?
entry.content:
You are welcome!

SAP Universal ID stays, and you can continue using it to store your certifications, reputation and achievements.

What changes is that SAP Universal ID will no longer serve as an identity provider. This is an inevitable technical prerequisite for achieving the broader objective of enabling customers to bring their corporate identity providers. The Account Switcher functionality will also return to ensure S-Users can be switched.
